York set for 2023 local council elections

02/05/2023

Lib Dems and Labour battle it out to take overall majority control of the City of York Council.

Image by andy

By James Clay

On 4 May, York residents will head to the polling stations to cast their votes in the 2023 local elections.

The York City Council is currently run by a Liberal Democrat and Green Party coalition.

The University of York campus sits in the Hull Road ward, where previously Labour has safely secured seats on the council, as seen in 2019 where three Labour councillors were elected. Whilst Labour is eager to maintain this stronghold, the Liberal Democrats are targeting the ward with the aim of taking overall control of the council.

Conversations on the doorstep point to a number of York-wide concerns the electorate will be keeping in mind on 4 May.

Some highlight how the Blue Badge Ban has greatly affected their experience travelling to the city, others are concerned about the continued lack of affordable housing and the issues surrounding sustainability.

The Blue Badge Ban stops disabled parking in pedestrianised areas of the city which was initially introduced as part of lockdown measures, but was made permanent in 2021. The council argued it was necessary in order to install anti-terror defences, and agreed that mitigations to the ban would be put in place.

Labour and Conservatives are keen to use the Blue Badge Ban (which both parties are prepared to reverse) as one of the main talking points on the doorstep. They argue that the Liberal Democrat-Green coalition has recklessly enforced this policy, which they argue sidelines disabled people from accessing the same facilities as easily as everyone else.

On a visit to the University of Yorkâ€™s Department of Health Sciences, Labour leader Keir Starmer, found the Blue Badge Ban to be â€œshockingâ€ and promised that a Labour controlled council would reverse it.

Whether this is likely to significantly damage the Liberal Democrat-Green coalition is yet to be seen, however the Reverse the Ban protest outside the national Liberal Democrat conference in York, certainly suggests there is strong feeling amongst campaigners that the decision is â€œdiscriminatoryâ€. Labour Councillor Pete Kilbane suggested that the decision wasnâ€™t thought through, as mitigations to the ban should have been implemented before the decision came into place.

Candidates report that residents are particularly concerned about housing in the city. Labour pledge to build â€œ100% affordable housingâ€ with plans to use sale receipts for future â€œhouse-building schemesâ€. The Conservatives plan to freeze council tax to â€œkeep more money in your household budget by eliminating wasteful spending at City of York Councilâ€. And the Liberal Democrats aim to build over 4,000 new affordable homes over the next 15 years.

Further issues facing York residents include parking, the behaviour of stag and hen doâ€™s and as is typical in a local election, the infamous state of our roads. However, the local elections will show a greater sentiment beyond the condition of potholes, to the state of British politics. The results on 4 May will represent the general feeling of the last four years; since the handling of Covid-19, the Johnson and Truss downfall and the various scandals Sunak is involved in, including the failure to declare special interest in the proposed childcare legislation and supporting the former Deputy Prime Minister, Dominic Raab, despite bullying accusations. Whilst the Conservatives in York arenâ€™t expected to make many gains (and are even in some cases endorsing Labour candidates), this is a strong opportunity for the Liberal Democrats to attract disillusioned Tory voters and a significant chance for Labour to make important gains ahead of the 2024 General Election.

There are concerns over the impact of the new Voter ID criteria, especially on how young people will be affected. Critics are worried that students will mistake their student ID as credible identification for the local election and therefore miss out on voting. Instead, voters can use but are not limited to, a British passport or a driving licence issued by the UK.

Some have called it voter suppression as those over 60 who have an Oyster card are eligible to vote with this form of ID, however if a young person over the age of 18 wanted to use an Oyster card as identification, this would be denied. Furthermore, critics have argued the new requirements disadvantage certain groups who either donâ€™t have the time nor finance to take these extra steps in order to vote, especially since encouraging people to vote in local elections is hard enough.

Across the country, the local elections are expected to send a strong message to Sunakâ€™s government and potentially indicate how next yearâ€™s general election may turn out. Here in York, it seems the battle lies between the Lib Dems and Labour for control of the council.
